(Sorry this took so long, I got this killer ear infection, grrrr>.<)

Tavatron nearly stopped breathing when Dinobot leaned in close to her. She 
listened carefully to what he said next. She was seeking the truth; that was 
all she ever wanted. He didn�t have to worry about hurting her. The truth, 
no matter how harmful, was better than even the kindest lie. Well, that was 
how she saw things anyway. She didn�t want him to lie and say some idiotic 
chauvinistic phrase just to shut her up. Tavatron�s breathing slowly 
returned to normal as Dinobot backed away. She never knew how to react when 
a �bot got too close physically. Sometimes it bothered her, and sometimes it 
didn�t. Oddly enough when Dinobot was near her she felt fine, if anything a 
mild sense of comfort. Still, she was relieved when he backed up.

Tavatron watched calmly as he continued to speak. She appeared unconcerned, 
as if this was exactly what she had been expecting when in fact she was 
quite stunned. He really did care. He wanted to be sure that she was safe. 
She could only imagine how much will he had worked up just to say that he 
cared! He rarely even showed it much less spoke it! She remained speechless 
for the next few moments, unsure of what to say and how to say it. It just 
dawned on her how much she had hurt him by leaving his side when he was 
injured. Tavatron looked away, she didn�t want to look at him right now. She 
felt terrible. She was a disappointment, to herself and to everyone around 
her. Everyone she had ever known, ever cared for, was dead or long gone to 
some far off space colony. They had abandoned her, whether intentionally or 
not they had left, and she had done the exact same thing to Dinobot.

The wind had picked up again� it was blowing up small waves of dust across 
the empty plains. Tavatron coughed slightly as she sat up. She had always 
noticed little things like that. Especially the wind. After the incident on 
the colony being able to predict the weather became a matter of life and 
death. If you didn�t know when the rains or the dust storms were coming you 
were as good as dead. There seemed to be similar situations in the more arid 
climates of this planet, especially the deserts. The sandstorms were very 
much like the old dust storms. Perhaps that was why she stuck to the forests 
and mountain regions. She hated open spaces, always had and always will.

Tavatron sighed again. She was ignoring the matter at hand and she knew it. 
She was hoping to buy some time with her last question. She didn�t want to 
deal with this. Not now, not ever again. She had fought long and hard to 
forget, but just couldn�t. The faces and facts of what transpired all those 
years ago were burned in her memory, and no amount of reprogramming was 
going to erase them. Tavatron stood, her fur was covered in a fine layer of 
dust but was otherwise presentable. She quickly brushed out most of it, but 
couldn�t reach that one spot on her back. The gentle cawing of the crows 
drifted through the air as Tavatron turned in the direction of the CF. She 
slowly began to walk towards it as she spoke:

"We better get back to base."

After taking a few steps she stopped, watching as a hawk drifted lazily 
above. It circled once and then dove into some tall grass. She couldn�t put 
this off any longer. Dinobot not only deserved an explanation but in part 
she wanted to give one. Tavatron took a deep breath and continued, right now 
she was beginning to wish she was that hawk�s latest meal. It was taking all 
the will and courage she had and then some to talk to him about this. She 
was hoping it was all behind her. Apparently, it wasn�t:

"I know there is no excuse for my earlier actions, nor should there be. I 
cannot change the past� nor run from it any longer."

Tavatron spoke the last part in a whisper. Her ears swiveled back and forth, 
absorbing every sound. This planet held so many secrets, a pity she never 
had the time to explore more of it:

"If you still desire an explanation you may have it."
